classification.notes: Unapproved peptide commonly discussed in recovery contexts. Often conflated with Thymosin Beta-4 (Tβ4) biology; products vary and claims frequently exceed evidence.

status.human_use_note: TB-500 is not an approved therapeutic drug. Evidence for many recovery claims is primarily preclinical; human evidence for TB-500 specifically is limited.

structure.sequence_oneletter: Pep-Talk curation pending: we’re reviewing the evidence and will expand this section soon.

risk.rationale: Key uncertainty is that many benefits are inferred from broader thymosin beta-4 biology and animal work, while real-world risk includes sourcing purity and unregulated administration. Developmental risk flagged due to common youth-athlete interest and limited safety characterization.

overview.title: What it is
overview.text: TB-500 is a peptide product marketed in recovery contexts, often linked to thymosin beta-4 biology. Many claims rely on preclinical data; human outcome evidence for TB-500 as sold is limited.

observed_exposure_ranges.notes: Descriptive only. This app does not provide protocols. Not instructions.

developmental_risk_block.title: Developmental / Adolescent risk
developmental_risk_block.text: Because TB-500 claims are often preclinical and safety is not well characterized, adolescents should treat uncertainty as meaningful risk, especially given real-world sourcing variability.

current_outlook_bullets: a peptide product marketed in recovery contexts, often linked to thymosin beta-4 biology
soft tissue healing after overuse or injury

evidence.title: Thymosin beta-4 biology and tissue repair (review; context for claims)
evidence.notes: Broad review of thymosin beta-4 biology; supports mechanistic plausibility in animals but does not establish TB-500 outcomes in humans.

changelog.detail: Added recovery-context peptide entry with strong preclinical framing; flagged developmental risk and sourcing uncertainty.

practical.bottom_line: TB-500 is a market name often associated with thymosin beta-4–related fragments and is commonly discussed for injury recovery. Most supportive data is preclinical or indirect, and real-world risk is driven by product identity confusion and unregulated sourcing.
benefits: Soft-tissue recovery interest after overuse or injury
Return-to-training support interest during rehab periods
Joint comfort and mobility support interest in recovery discussions
side_effects_serious: Allergic reaction with hives, facial swelling, or trouble breathing
Chest pain, fainting, or severe shortness of breath
Severe swelling, rapidly spreading redness, or drainage at an injection site
who_should_be_cautious: Active cancer or recent cancer treatment

practical.bottom_line: TB-500 is marketed as a recovery peptide linked to thymosin beta-4 fragments. Real-world use centers on soft-tissue recovery claims; human evidence is limited.
benefits: general “inflammation control” claims in some communities (often overstated)
sometimes grouped with other injury-healing compounds in recovery culture
side_effects_serious: severe allergic reaction symptoms (hives, facial swelling, trouble breathing)
persistent chest pain, fainting, or severe shortness of breath
who_should_be_cautious: people with active cancer or a high cancer-risk history (tissue-growth signaling context)
anyone using unverified sources (contamination and mislabeling risk)
